comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Plus there's a great new resource online from today that some of you may be interested in - The Down Survey of Ireland (from the 17th century). And you can overlay Google Maps to compare then and now. You can have a good old explore of it.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
66311327@N05
comment._content: It exists a pocket guide about these stones: "Turas Cholm Cille" by Gerard Cunningham. (dqxnjpkv3z1u2.cloudfront.net/Image/646f9d38-9f7b-df11-ab1...) The photo shows Stad 2 - An tSráid. "Prayers recited at this station are five Our Fathers, five Hail Marys, five Glories, and the Creed."

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Ye Rime of Ye Antient Limericker Now here's a small story absurd 'Bout this old Cross, so I've heard - It points to the sky Allowing the eye To look for what's known as The Bird.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Yes, it does look like the "bird" alright, nice one!

comment.author: 75556178@N05
comment._content: This stone looks a lot like the stone mentioned on this website. www.daramolloy.com/CelticWedOnAran.html It is located near St.Kieran's monastery on the Aran islands. Colmcille spent some time here before heading off on his missions. What the consequences were for the monks who accidentally touched this stone have not been recorded. Welcome back.
